texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Sometimes automation is your best friend and sometimes it isn't. Typically, when two devices are connected via ethernet cables,  they negotiate  the best speed they can manage across a network link. They also try to agree on whether they can run full or half duplex across the network link.
texts.text: Sometimes automation is your best friend and sometimes it isn't. Typically, when two devices are connected via ethernet cables,  they negotiate  the best speed they can manage across a network link. They also try to agree on whether they can run full or half duplex across the network link.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Most of the time, this works beautifully. It can break down with strange networking configs, damaged adapters, or finicky cables. In those situations, if you can rule out physical damage to any parts involved, you may need to disable autonegotiation to get the functionality you want.
texts.text: Most of the time, this works beautifully. It can break down with strange networking configs, damaged adapters, or finicky cables. In those situations, if you can rule out physical damage to any parts involved, you may need to disable autonegotiation to get the functionality you want.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Slow home network
texts.text: Slow home network

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My home internet connection has a 400 megabit per second downlink, but noticed my downloads were slower this week and if someone was actively downloading something, such as an Xbox update, the internet latency shot up past 300ms. A few speed tests later and I found my internet speeds were limited to about 88 megabits per second.
texts.text: My home internet connection has a 400 megabit per second downlink, but noticed my downloads were slower this week and if someone was actively downloading something, such as an Xbox update, the internet latency shot up past 300ms. A few speed tests later and I found my internet speeds were limited to about 88 megabits per second.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My home firewall is a Dell Optiplex 7060 with an Intel I350-T2 dual-port gigabit ethernet card. My internet-facing NIC connects to a Netgear CM500-NAS cable modem. A quick check of my firewall's external adapter revealed the problem:
texts.text: My home firewall is a Dell Optiplex 7060 with an Intel I350-T2 dual-port gigabit ethernet card. My internet-facing NIC connects to a Netgear CM500-NAS cable modem. A quick check of my firewall's external adapter revealed the problem:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# ethtool enp2s0f0 | grep Speed
	Speed: 100Mb/s
texts.text:
# ethtool enp2s0f0 | grep Speed
	Speed: 100Mb/s

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Well that's certainly not right. The I350 is a gigabit card and the CM500-NAS is rated for speeds well over 100 mb/s. Rebooting the cable modem and the router itself didn't change anything. I replaced the ethernet cable with a few others and there was no change there, either.
texts.text: Well that's certainly not right. The I350 is a gigabit card and the CM500-NAS is rated for speeds well over 100 mb/s. Rebooting the cable modem and the router itself didn't change anything. I replaced the ethernet cable with a few others and there was no change there, either.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: At this point, I was worried that my cable modem or adapter might have malfunction. At least there's one more option.
texts.text: At this point, I was worried that my cable modem or adapter might have malfunction. At least there's one more option.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Manually set the link speed
texts.text: Manually set the link speed

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Before we approach this section, here's a reminder:
texts.text: Before we approach this section, here's a reminder:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: 💣  Be sure that you have some other way to get into your system if manually setting the link speed fails.
texts.text: 💣  Be sure that you have some other way to get into your system if manually setting the link speed fails.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If the system is remote to you, such as a dedicated server, virtual machine, or a faraway edge device that requires a 5 hour drive, you may want to consider other options. There's a chance that manually setting the link speed may cause the link negotiation to fail entirely.
texts.text: If the system is remote to you, such as a dedicated server, virtual machine, or a faraway edge device that requires a 5 hour drive, you may want to consider other options. There's a chance that manually setting the link speed may cause the link negotiation to fail entirely.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: systemd-networkd gives you plenty of low-level control over network interfaces using the  link files . These files have two parts:
texts.text: systemd-networkd gives you plenty of low-level control over network interfaces using the  link files . These files have two parts:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: a
texts.text: a

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: a
texts.text: a

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We need two of these configurations in the
texts.text: We need two of these configurations in the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: [Link]
texts.text: [Link]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: section:
texts.text: section:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: BitsPerSecond=
texts.text: BitsPerSecond=

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Duplex=
texts.text: Duplex=

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In this example, I'll match the interface on its MAC address and set the speed/duplex:
texts.text: In this example, I'll match the interface on its MAC address and set the speed/duplex:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# /etc/systemd/networkd/internet.link
[Match]
MACAddress=a0:36:9f:6e:52:26

[Link]
BitsPerSecond=1G
Duplex=full
texts.text:
# /etc/systemd/networkd/internet.link
[Match]
MACAddress=a0:36:9f:6e:52:26

[Link]
BitsPerSecond=1G
Duplex=full

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We can apply the configuration change by restarting systemd-networkd:
texts.text: We can apply the configuration change by restarting systemd-networkd:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: systemctl restart systemd-networkd
texts.text: systemctl restart systemd-networkd

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now let's check the speeds:
texts.text: Now let's check the speeds:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# ethtool enp2s0f0 | grep Speed
	Speed: 1000Mb/s
texts.text:
# ethtool enp2s0f0 | grep Speed
	Speed: 1000Mb/s

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Perfect! 🎉
texts.text: Perfect! 🎉

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Digging for answers
texts.text: Digging for answers

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Once the network speeds were working well again and my kids weren't upset by glitches in their Netflix shows, I decided to look for issues that might be causing the negotiation to fail. Some quick checks of the network card show some potential issues:
texts.text: Once the network speeds were working well again and my kids weren't upset by glitches in their Netflix shows, I decided to look for issues that might be causing the negotiation to fail. Some quick checks of the network card show some potential issues:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# ethtool -S enp2s0f0 | grep error
     rx_crc_errors: 22
     rx_missed_errors: 0
     tx_aborted_errors: 0
     tx_carrier_errors: 0
     tx_window_errors: 0
     rx_long_length_errors: 0
     rx_short_length_errors: 0
     rx_align_errors: 0
     rx_errors: 33
     tx_errors: 0
     rx_length_errors: 0
     rx_over_errors: 0
     rx_frame_errors: 0
     rx_fifo_errors: 0
     tx_fifo_errors: 0
     tx_heartbeat_errors: 0
texts.text:
# ethtool -S enp2s0f0 | grep error
     rx_crc_errors: 22
     rx_missed_errors: 0
     tx_aborted_errors: 0
     tx_carrier_errors: 0
     tx_window_errors: 0
     rx_long_length_errors: 0
     rx_short_length_errors: 0
     rx_align_errors: 0
     rx_errors: 33
     tx_errors: 0
     rx_length_errors: 0
     rx_over_errors: 0
     rx_frame_errors: 0
     rx_fifo_errors: 0
     tx_fifo_errors: 0
     tx_heartbeat_errors: 0

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I've swapped network cables between the devices a few times and these errors continue to appear frequently. My I350 card is several years old and discontinued from Intel, so this could be the culprit. It's also been moved between quite a few different computers over the years. A replacement with something new might be in my future.
texts.text: I've swapped network cables between the devices a few times and these errors continue to appear frequently. My I350 card is several years old and discontinued from Intel, so this could be the culprit. It's also been moved between quite a few different computers over the years. A replacement with something new might be in my future.
